_GeneralInformation.Description: This dataset is a collection of component-level damage models from the literature and public resources. Every entry has one or more corresponding publications identified that provide more information about its calibration and application limits.

References.abdelhady2022: Abdelhady, A. U., S. M. J. Spence, and J. McCormick. 2022. Risk and fragility assessment of residential wooden buildings subject to hurricane winds. Structural Safety, 94: 102137. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.strusafe.2021.102137.
References.angeles2021: Angeles, K., D. Patsialis, A. A. Taflanidis, T. L. Kijewski-Correa, A. Buccellato, and C. Vardeman. 2021. Advancing the Design of Resilient and Sustainable Buildings: An Integrated Life-Cycle Analysis. J. Struct. Eng., 147 (3): 04020341. https://doi.org/10.1061/(ASCE)ST.1943-541X.0002910.
References.barbato2013: Barbato, M., F. Petrini, V. U. Unnikrishnan, and M. Ciampoli. 2013. Performance-Based Hurricane Engineering (PBHE) framework. Structural Safety, 45: 24–35. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.strusafe.2013.07.002.
References.canfield1991: Canfield, L., S. Niu, and H. Liu. 1991. Uplift resistance of various rafter-wall connections. Forest Products Journal.
References.cheng2004: Cheng, J. 2004. Testing and analysis of the toe-nailed connection in the residential roof-to-wall system. Forest Products Journal, 54: 58–65.
References.cope2004: Cope, A. D. 2004. Predicting the vulnerability of typical residential buildings to hurricane damage. University of Florida.
References.datin2011: Datin, P. L., D. O. Prevatt, and W. Pang. 2011. Wind-Uplift Capacity of Residential Wood Roof-Sheathing Panels Retrofitted with Insulating Foam Adhesive. J. Archit. Eng., 17 (4): 144–154. https://doi.org/10.1061/(ASCE)AE.1943-5568.0000034.
References.dong2016: Dong, Y., and Y. Li. 2016. Risk-based assessment of wood residential construction subjected to hurricane events considering indirect and environmental loss. Sustainable and Resilient Infrastructure, 1 (1–2): 46–62. Taylor & Francis. https://doi.org/10.1080/23789689.2016.1179051.
References.grayson2013: Grayson, J. M., W. Pang, and S. Schiff. 2013. Building envelope failure assessment framework for residential communities subjected to hurricanes. Engineering Structures, 51: 245–258. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.engstruct.2013.01.027.
References.gurley2005: Gurley, K., J. P. Pinelli, C. Subramanian, A. Cope, L. Zhang, J. Murphree, A. Artiles, P. Misra, S. Gulati, and E. Simiu. 2005. Florida Public Hurricane Loss Projection Model engineering team final report volume II: Predicting the vulnerability of typical residential buildings to hurricane damage. Technical report. Florida International University: International Hurricane Research Center.
References.jain2020: Jain, A., A. A. Bhusar, D. B. Roueche, and D. O. Prevatt. 2020. Engineering-Based Tornado Damage Assessment: Numerical Tool for Assessing Tornado Vulnerability of Residential Structures. Front. Built Environ., 6. Frontiers. https://doi.org/10.3389/fbuil.2020.00089.
References.kakareko2021: Kakareko, G., S. Jung, S. Mishra, and O. A. Vanli. 2021. Bayesian capacity model for hurricane vulnerability estimation. Structure and Infrastructure Engineering, 17 (5): 638–648. Taylor & Francis. https://doi.org/10.1080/15732479.2020.1760318.
References.lee2005: Lee, K. H., and D. V. Rosowsky. 2005. Fragility assessment for roof sheathing failure in high wind regions. Engineering Structures, 27 (6): 857–868. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.engstruct.2004.12.017.
References.li2006: Li, Y., and B. R. Ellingwood. 2006. Hurricane damage to residential construction in the US: Importance of uncertainty modeling in risk assessment. Engineering Structures, 28 (7): 1009–1018. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.engstruct.2005.11.005
References.lin2019: Lin, S.-Y., W.-C. Chuang, L. Xu, S. El-Tawil, S. M. J. Spence, V. R. Kamat, C. C. Menassa, and J. McCormick. 2019. Framework for Modeling Interdependent Effects in Natural Disasters: Application to Wind Engineering. Journal of Structural Engineering, 145 (5): 04019025. American Society of Civil Engineers. https://doi.org/10.1061/(ASCE)ST.1943-541X.0002310.
References.minor1998: Minor, J. E., and H. S. Norville. 1998. A simple window glass design chart. Journal of Wind Engineering and Industrial Aerodynamics, 77–78: 197–204. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0167-6105(98)00143-3.
References.norville1985: Norville, H. S., and J. E. Minor. 1985. STRENGTH OF WEATHERED WINDOW GLASS. American Ceramic Society Bulletin, 64: 1467–1470.
References.park2014: Park, S., J. W. Van De Lindt, and Y. Li. 2014. ABV Procedure Combined with Mechanistic Response Modeling for Roof- and Surge-Loss Estimation in Hurricanes. J. Perform. Constr. Facil., 28 (2): 206–215. https://doi.org/10.1061/(ASCE)CF.1943-5509.0000397.
References.peng2013: Peng, J. 2013. Modeling natural disaster risk management: Integrating the roles of insurance and retrofit and multiple stakeholder perspectives. Ph.D. United States -- Delaware: University of Delaware.
References.puga2015: Puga, H., B. A. Olmos, L. Olmos, J. M. Jara, and M. Jara. 2015. Damage assessment of curtain wall glass. J. Phys.: Conf. Ser., 628 (1): 012052. IOP Publishing. https://doi.org/10.1088/1742-6596/628/1/012052.
References.reed1996: Reed, T. D., D. V. Rosowsky, and S. D. Schiff. 1996. Roof rafter to top-plate connections in coastal residential construction. 458–465.
References.reed1997: Reed, T. D., D. V. Rosowsky, and S. D. Schiff. 1997. Uplift Capacity of Light-Frame Rafter to Top Plate Connections. Journal of Architectural Engineering, 3 (4): 156–163. American Society of Civil Engineers. https://doi.org/10.1061/(ASCE)1076-0431(1997)3:4(156).
References.rosowsky1996: Rosowsky, D., and S. Schiff. 1996. Probabilistic Modeling of Roof Sheathing Uplift Capacity. Probabilistic Mechanics and Structural Reliability.
References.rosowsky1999: Rosowsky, D. V., and N. Cheng. 1999. Reliability of Light-Frame Roofs in High-Wind Regions. I: Wind Loads. Journal of Structural Engineering, 125 (7): 725–733. American Society of Civil Engineers. https://doi.org/10.1061/(ASCE)0733-9445(1999)125:7(725).
References.shanmugam2009: Shanmugam, B., B. G. Nielson, and D. O. Prevatt. 2009. Statistical and analytical models for roof components in existing light-framed wood structures. Engineering Structures, 31 (11): 2607–2616. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.engstruct.2009.06.009.
References.shdid2011: Shdid, C. A., A. Mirmiran, T.-L. Wang, D. Jimenez, and P. Huang. 2011. Uplift Capacity and Impact Resistance of Roof Tiles. Pract. Period. Struct. Des. Constr., 16 (3): 121–129. https://doi.org/10.1061/(ASCE)SC.1943-5576.0000081.
References.shen2013: Shen, Y. 2013. Assessing the wind resistance of sectional door systems for facilities in hurricane-prone areas through full- and component-scale experimental methods and finite element analysis. Ph.D. United States -- Florida: University of Florida.
References.unnikrishnan2017: Unnikrishnan, V. U., and M. Barbato. 2017. Multihazard Interaction Effects on the Performance of Low-Rise Wood-Frame Housing in Hurricane-Prone Regions. Journal of Structural Engineering, 143 (8): 04017076. American Society of Civil Engineers. https://doi.org/10.1061/(ASCE)ST.1943-541X.0001797.
References.vickery2006: Vickery, P. J., P. F. Skerlj, J. Lin, L. A. Twisdale, M. A. Young, and F. M. Lavelle. 2006. HAZUS-MH Hurricane Model Methodology. II: Damage and Loss Estimation. Nat. Hazards Rev., 7 (2): 94–103. https://doi.org/10.1061/(ASCE)1527-6988(2006)7:2(94).
References.yau2011: Yau, S. C. 2011. Wind Hazard Risk Assessment and Management for Structures. Ph.D. United States -- New Jersey: Princeton University.

RWC.toe_nail.straps.001.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and a small strap inside
RWC.toe_nail.straps.001.Comments: The small strap is located on the inside of the wall.

RWC.toe_nail.straps.002.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and a small strap outside
RWC.toe_nail.straps.002.Comments: The small strap is located on the outside of the wall.

RWC.toe_nail.straps.003.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and small straps on both sides
RWC.toe_nail.straps.003.Comments: Two small straps are installed, one inside and one outside of the wall.

RWC.toe_nail.straps.004.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, a small strap outside, and plywood nailed.
RWC.toe_nail.straps.004.Comments: The small strap is located on the outside of the wall. A plywood is nailed to the plate on the wall as spacer.

RWC.toe_nail.straps.005.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, a small strap outside, and plywood not nailed.
RWC.toe_nail.straps.005.Comments: The small strap is located on the outside of the wall. A plywood is installed as spacer but not nailed to the plate on the wall.

RWC.toe_nail.straps.006.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and a large strap outside
RWC.toe_nail.straps.006.Comments: The large strap is located on the outside of the wall.

RWC.toe_nail.straps.007.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and a large strap inside
RWC.toe_nail.straps.007.Comments: The large strap is located on the inside of the wall.

RWC.epoxy.001.Comments: Epoxy set for one week, no toe nails used.

RWC.toe_nail.epoxy.001.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and epoxy.
RWC.toe_nail.epoxy.001.Comments: Epoxy set for one week, toe-nailed when epoxy is wet.

RWC.toe_nail.epoxy.002.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and epoxy on small wood blocks.

RWC.toe_nail.epoxy.003.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and epoxy on small wood blocks.

RWC.toe_nail.epoxy.004.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and epoxy on large wood blocks.

RWC.toe_nail.adhesive.001.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and acrylic adhesive
RWC.toe_nail.adhesive.001.Comments: Adhesive set for one week, toe-nailed when adhesive is wet.

RWC.toe_nail.adhesive.002.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and soaked with acrylic adhesive.
RWC.toe_nail.adhesive.002.Comments: Wood first soaked for 24 hours, then toe-nailed when adhesive is wet.

RWC.toe_nail.adhesive.003.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and acrylic adhesive on small wood blocks.

RWC.toe_nail.adhesive.004.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and 1/4 inch acrylic adhesive bead

RWC.toe_nail.adhesive.005.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and 1/2 inch acrylic adhesive bead

RWC.toe_nail.adhesive.006.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and foaming polyurethane adhesive.

RWC.toe_nail.002.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and Simpson Strong-Tie H10.
RWC.toe_nail.002.Comments: Simpson Strong-Tie H10 metal connector installed on every truss.

RWC.hurricane_clip.001a.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Hurricane Clip H2.5.

RWC.hurricane_clip.001b.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Hurricane Clip H2.5.

RWC.toe_nail.003.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, 2-16d layout.

RWC.toe_nail.004.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, 3-8d layout.

RWC.toe_nail.005.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, 3-16d layout.

RWC.toe_nail.006a.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, 2-16d layout, box nails.

RWC.toe_nail.006b.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, 2-16d layout, box nails.

RWC.toe_nail.006c.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, 2-16d layout, box nails.

WIN.regular.003b.Description: Window on a 2-story building with 2 large windows
